{"comments": {"id": 2460, "count": 235, "talk_id": 1102}, "threadId": 2460, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "1102", "description": "With never-before-seen video, primatologist Isabel Behncke Izquierdo (a TED Fellow) shows how bonobo ape society learns from constantly playing -- solo, with friends, even as a prelude to sex. Indeed, play appears to be the bonobos' key to problem-solving and avoiding conflict. If it works for our close cousins, why not for us?", "event": "TED2011", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Isabel Behncke: Evolution's gift of play, from bonobo apes to humans", "slug": "isabel_behncke_evolution_s_gift_of_play_from_bonobo_apes_to_humans", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "968", "slug": "isabel_behncke_izquierdo", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Isabel", "lastname": "Behncke", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Primatologist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/657309ed989cd2d72e8729b5b805d31ffbfb7880_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Isabel Behncke applies an evolutionary lens to human questions like: Why do we play?", "whylisten": "

Isabel Behncke (MSc University College London, MPhil, Cambridge University; PhD, Oxford University) is a New York- and Oxford-based behavioural and evolutionary scientist working on the nature of social animals … including humans. She’s from the mountains of Chile and loves wild things.

After walking 3000+ km in the jungles of Congo observing the social behaviour of bonobo apes -- our closest living relatives -- in field research, Dr. Behncke now applies an evolutionary lens to questions that lie at the core of social life and creativity: Why do we go to festivals? Why does trust require risk taking? Why do adults need to play in order to not just feel alive, but also maintain health, creativity and social bonds? Why do cities need to be not just ‘smart’ but also enjoyable? And crucially why is it that the more digital we get, the more understanding of evolution we need?

She enjoys consulting and engagement in different forms, has spoken at WIRED, the G20, House of Lords, United Nations, twice at the main TED event, and around the fire in Patagonia. She also has been part of numerous radio programmes, including NPR and BBC Radio 4. She has been featured in a number of television documentaries (BBC and National Geographic) and independent cinema (e.g., ‘Bounce: How the Ball taught the World to Play’).

"middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Primatologist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/657309ed989cd2d72e8729b5b805d31ffbfb7880_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Isabel Behncke applies an evolutionary lens to human questions like: Why do we play?", "whylisten": "

Isabel Behncke (MSc University College London, MPhil, Cambridge University; PhD, Oxford University) is a New York- and Oxford-based behavioural and evolutionary scientist working on the nature of social animals … including humans. She’s from the mountains of Chile and loves wild things.

After walking 3000+ km in the jungles of Congo observing the social behaviour of bonobo apes -- our closest living relatives -- in field research, Dr. Behncke now applies an evolutionary lens to questions that lie at the core of social life and creativity: Why do we go to festivals? Why does trust require risk taking? Why do adults need to play in order to not just feel alive, but also maintain health, creativity and social bonds? Why do cities need to be not just ‘smart’ but also enjoyable? And crucially why is it that the more digital we get, the more understanding of evolution we need?

She enjoys consulting and engagement in different forms, has spoken at WIRED, the G20, House of Lords, United Nations, twice at the main TED event, and around the fire in Patagonia. She also has been part of numerous radio programmes, including NPR and BBC Radio 4. She has been featured in a number of television documentaries (BBC and National Geographic) and independent cinema (e.g., ‘Bounce: How the Ball taught the World to Play’).

"}], "speaker_name": "Isabel Behncke", "tags": ["TED Fellows", "animals", "culture", "play", "science"], "title": "Evolution's gift of play, from bonobo apes to humans", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 894065}]}
